description.text: By changing the resolution back down to 55x55 pixels I can actually slice the skull in Simplify3D! Printed fine without any tearing, it was probably due to the way too thin walls at 85x85. It is by default scaled to 88%, the lowest it slices in Simplify3D. Scaling it any further may result in slicing problems or tearing depending on your slicer/printer. The light source needs to be at the northpole of the imaginary sphere the skull is intersected with, I marked it on three pictures. The light should come in a 45° angle to the base of the skull, it is quite fidgety to get it right, I did it with a bare LED chip, a very thin flashlight might also work.

title: Thickened Large Idler Gear for Dual Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis

description.text:
The original Dual Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis by gzumwalt is a pretty awesome mechanical toy. the only problem i had printing it was the Gear_Idler_Large which has 2 gear parts. the smaller one has a pretty thin wall (0.4mm) which should print fine with a 0.4mm nozzle but would not slice in slic3r.
i could not get it to slice properly on cura 2.4beta, though people have commented that it slices just fine for them.
as i do not have a simplify3d license - i could not test that as well.

my solution was simple - import into fusion360 and convert to brep. i then thickened the outer wall of the small top gear to ~0.55mm which should slice just fine in all slicers.
the original design has enough of a tolerance that this does not effect the mechanical part at all, and after a few weeks of it being thrown around and played with - i can attest that it is strong enough.

if you are using slic3r - i highly recommend that you use prusa research's version (located here: https://github.com/prusa3d/Slic3r/releases ) and that you disable the "detect thin walls" option under print settings -> layers and perimeters, as that will guarantee that the wall is sliced and printed properly.

Printer:

mgn12 cartesian

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.120mm

Infill:

50% (cubic infill)

Notes:

printed with the "detect thin walls" option DISABLED in slic3r v1.33.3 by prusa research (here: https://github.com/prusa3d/Slic3r/releases )

3 perimeters, 3 bottom layers, 4 top layers

description.text:
Y-axis motor bracket for dampener (printed for the Prusa i3, but could probably work with other models)  
When I first received my motors for the RepRap Prusa i3 I was building, they came with this wierd metal/rubber plate attached to the top. Not knowing what it was, I removed the plate and attached the motors to my original brackets (which required their removal anyways). Later, I found out these plates were dampeners, used to cut down on vibration and noise. My x-axis was easy to install the dampener with the original bracket, but my y-axis bracket could not hold both the dampener and the motor, thus, this new bracket was born!

Printed on my Prusa i3 for my Prusa i3 .25 layer height
3 perimeters and .5 density hex infill -- for strength
2 mm brim -- to aid in keeping corner from peeling off the bed Should print fine, but make sure the screw insets are on top of the print because it'll have a hard time printing with those on the bottom. You will have to flip the print 180 degrees to achieve this. Expand the pictures to get the best instructions!
The pictures should explain well enough how to install this bracket. One thing to note is that the screw insets are on the wrong side. So, the screw-head will sit on the opposite side of the inset, but this doesn't affect anything. Make sure the screws connecting the dampener to the motor are tight, and the screws connecting the bracket to the dampener don't go far enough to touch the motor -- the dampener needs to be the only thing between the motor and the bracket -- the motor should not touch the bracket in any way besides through the dampener. I had to used stacked washers in order to achieve this given my set of bolts at hand.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/aDaSuZzBf3J

title: Airsoft Double Mobius Mount for 20mm Picatinny Rail

description.text:
This is a double mount for two Mobius cameras. It allows you to capture footage both facing away and towards you, giving you some nice views of the day. I personally use this mount for airsoft. It works for 20mm picatinny rails and, once clamped down, it will fit nicely and won't move whilst mounted. The cameras will have a little bit of play once mounted in but nothing to really worry about.

I actually did this model on both the Up Plus as well as a 3D Systems SLA Printer just to see which would be better. In my opinion, the SLA printer worked better due to me being able to cook the resin and make it very solid. Even though the SLA is the best option for this, the ABS version from the Up Plus was also good and strong.

Things to remember:

  1. Make it solid - Otherwise the walls of the mount will break.
  2. Remember supports - Otherwise the bottom the the mount won't print properly and you need it correct in order to mount it to rails.
  3. Print the model with the mobius mount at the top, as otherwise it would be very difficult to get the support off of the model.

Finally in order for the mount to be mounted to the rail you'll need a standard mounting nut and bolt.

title: box for breadboard & arduino (with laser cut)

description.text: A box for long breadboard (17x6 cm).

This data will be probably useless without few changes, because every laser has a different thicknes of cut and every matherial is a quite different too, even when documentation says something else;). So, at first is good to do some tests of joints in your vector editor.
Because there is no other chance to check laser cutted line thickness.
Make a one shape with pins and second with holes with same size.
Use the "transform each" function to make a different sizes of every pins. And make the variations of the part with pins.
Change the size for 102%, 104% 106% etc...
Send it to the laser to find the best tight joint.
Then use this scales of the pins and holes for whole project. Assembling:
When you done everything good you won't need to glue the parts of box together.
To join the breadboard to box is good to use cable ties or 3M dual lock. PS:Thank to FabLab Rotterdam staff with help.

This is a simple, but elegant, rear lenscap for Minolta SR (also known as MC and MD) mount lenses. These lenses were used on Minolta SLRs from 1958 on, but were essentially orphaned after Minolta moved to an autofocus mount in 1985 because the SR flange-to-film distance is less than most other mounts can adapt without loss of infinity focus. However, they work great on mirrorless cameras such as the Sony A7/A7R. You can still buy rear caps, but this one has a bit more style.

Well, this isn't quite an easy print. The thing that needs to be precise is the ramp that holds the cap on the lens, but printing that face-up means that the back of the cap is printed as unsupported spans. Printed without supports, there will be poorly-bonded strands, but they'll be on the inside, so they don't really matter.  
I printed it in PLA at 0.25mm and 25-40% fill. Blue and white were Minolta's packaging colors, but obviously any color(s) would work. I used a toothpick to place white paint in the embossed lettering; it isn't great, but it is readable enough.  
The "minolta" text is simply a way to identify the mount; this lenscap is in no way a Minolta product. (The two STL files differ only in how much the text is rotated; they both work, but one or the other lines up text better with the top of the lens, depending on minor variations in lens flange thickness -- official lens caps don't line-up printing on them consistently either.) Although the mount is technically called SR, and MC and MD are just lens designations adding features to SR, I figured it would be easiest to identify the mount by a pre-1981-style lowercase "minolta" as seen on the SRT and other SR-mount cameras. Later Minolta cameras used an uppercase logo which most people would associate with the incompatible AF mount (which is now also known as Sony A mount).

A simple desktop universal joint.

Print (I made it all of ABS, .2mm layers):
4 - Forks
2 - Blocks
1 - Intermediate Shaft
1 - Crank
2 - Long Pivot Pins
4 - Short Pivot Pins
1 - Crank Shaft
1 - Drive Shaft
1 - Frame You'll get the best results if you glue everything together, although the parts are somewhat tight-fitting. Start by gluing the intermediate shaft in the bottom hole on two of the forks. Make sure the faces of the forks are parallel to each other. Glue the Drive Shaft to the bottom hole of the third Fork. Glue the crank on the end of the Crank Shaft. Slide the Crank Shaft Assembly thru one of the holes in the frame, and then glue on the forth Fork. Finish the assembly by using the Long and Short Pivot Pins to hold the Blocks in the Forks. Spin and enjoy!!

Elements of 3D Printing poster makes an excellent teaching tool that allows students to see the various settings that go into making a great 3D print!

***A special thank you to Tasker Smith and MIT's Pappalardo Lab (The most WICKED lab on campus) for the inspiration for this poster. @PappalardoLab

The "Essentials of 3D Printing" poster is used as a feature in your Makerspace, Fablab, or classroom. This teaching tool allows students to learn about the various settings that go into printing a model. The .STL files can be attached to the poster using glue or even velcro tape allowing for students to interact with the parts while choosing how to print their models.  Following the procedures outlines below this poster can be printed, and changed to meet your individual printers settings. 
*This poster was specifically designed around using a Makerbot Replicator with the Smart Extruder+. If you are using a different printer your print times and material usage will vary slightly but the understanding of what the various settings do remains the same.

Poster: The poster was designed to be printed at the standard poster size of 18" x 24" with each of the print files fitting in the 2"x 2" squares. If you choose to print the poster smaller or larger you will also need to change the print sizes accordingly. Depending on how you are wanting to have the poster viewed it might require you to put a stiff backing behind it. In the picture above the poster was glued onto some leftover student poster board. 3D Prints: If you have a Makerbot Replicator 5th Gen. or a Makerbot Replicator+ running the Smart Extruder+ you can download all of the pre-sliced .makerbot files below from the linked Google Drive folder. For printing these files you only need to add them to your USB stick and print directly from your printer. Makerbot Replicator w/ Smart Extruder https://goo.gl/fR2tRd
Makerbot Replicator+ w/ Smart Extruder https://goo.gl/tpw1jO (If you would like additional printers added to this list please leave a note in the comments) All of the prints require some work within the "Custom" settings menu of either the Makerbot Desktop software or their latest Makerbot Print software. For these instructions Makerbot Print will be used. Part Density: For the part density files they are all printed with 2 shells, which is the default setting, but you will need to change both the part density, and roof thickness setting. For each of the differing density you will need to change the infill density setting while keeping the roof thickness setting set at 0mm. The roof thickness setting allows you to see into the part so that the infill density can be viewed. (Image 1) Shells: Each of the shell files will be printed with 0% infill, 0mm roof thickness and vary the shell count accordingly for each print. (Image 2) Layer Height: Since differences in layer height can be best shown on curvy or organic models, the .STL file is topography of the rocky mountains. This file was created using the website Terrain 2 .STL which can be found at http://jthatch.com/Terrain2STL/. For the Layer height models you will need to make sure that you change back the infill to 5-10% and the roof thickness back to .8mm, and change the layer height accordingly for each model. (Image 3) Support: For this model all that is needed is to choose the support setting for the print. After the print is done you will want to leave the support on the model for the display. (Image 4) Raft: No changes to the print settings are needed for this model. Just leave the raft on the model for the display. Image 1 Image 2 Image 3 Image 4

comments.author: msrd0

comments.text: I used a multimeter to inspect the connector on the motherboard. I found out that the top one is the one that needs to be triggered, the second one is ground and the last one is +5V. The z-switch from anycubic triggered the pin to gnd and used an internal pull-up on the motherboard. I decided to leave it like this and connected a npn-transistor's emitter to the gnd and the collector to the trigger pin on the motherboard. Then I took a 10kR resistor and connected it to the base and to the indicator pin of the inductive sensor. I jused the empty third power connector of the power supply (+12V) to connect it to the power pins of the inductive sensor that should be between 6-36V. Double-check that your sensor has the same specifications before wiring it up!
comments.author: Danisky81

comments.text: Many thanks

comments.author: Danisky81

comments.text: An inductive sensor can detect metal objects like your print bed within a given range, most likely about 4mm. You can mount one on your print head (which I designed this thing for) and use it instead of the z switch of your printer to home the nozzle. If you modify the firmware (there is a great tutorial by Thomas Sanladerer on youtube) you can probe the z axis on multiple positions and detect the tilt between the z axis and the print bed.

comments.text: The biggest problem with my bed is that it is higher in the middle than at the edges. The inductive sensor can detect this quite accurate but I'd reccomend to fix the cable of it because when the head moves the cable moves the sensor a very little bit. Marlin in the current stable version (you can find one on my github account) only supports plane beds so inductive sensor is only used to get the tilt of it. But I've heard that newer version supports non-even beds with inductive sensors, so if you want you can try one of their release candidates!

title: Contour sanding grips / Cale à poncer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Cette petite cale à poncer permet grâce à différents profilés de poncer des courbes et des parties difficilement accessibles.
Je voulais avoir la possibilité de pouvoir changer de profilé en ayant qu'une seule partie principale. Cela est déjà plus pratique à stocker et permet d'imprimer rapidement le profilé qui nous intéresse.

  • Insérez l'écrou dans la partie principale
  • Choisissez le profilé et installez-le
  • Maintenir le profilé avec la vis
  • Insérez les bras métalliques provenant de la pince à clip de chaque côté de la partie principale
  • Pressez les bras de façon à écarter les pinces de la partie principale
  • Placez le papier à poncer et retirez les bras métalliques
  • Au boulot !

J'ai déjà fait un certain nombre de profilés, mais n'hésitez pas à faire les vôtres et les partager...

Liste des courses :

  • Une pince clip (40mm) pour récupérer les bras métalliques
  • Une vis de 16 à 20 mm en Ø3 mm avec un écrou

Conseil : pour maintenir le papier bien autour de certains profilés, j'ai utilisé un adhésif double face comme celui-ci : https://www.fasttech.com/p/6313602

These contours allow you to easily sand curves, profiles and other hard to get in areas.
I would like to have removal contours, it's easiest to store and faster to print.

  • Insert nut in the body
  • Choose one contour and install it
  • Hold contour with the screw
  • Insert metallic arms on the sides of the body
  • Press arms insert paper sanding and remove arms
  • Enjoy !

I made many contours but don't hesitate to make yours and share it...

BOM

  • Binder clip (40 mm) for arms
  • Ø3mm screw (16 or 20 mm) and nut

Tip : to maintain paper on contours, I use double sided adhesive tape like this one : https://www.fasttech.com/p/6313602

remixed_from.title: Bolt Hobbing Tool for Metal Lathe

description.text:
This is a tool to make M8 hobbing bolts.
It uses two 608 bearings to hold an 8mm bolt.
The tool assumes a lathe tool holder of at least 10x10mm... I used it on my Rotwerk EDM350DR and it worked fine :)

Print the hobbing tool at very high infill with support enabled (there is only a small amount of support required)
Remove support, press in the 608 bearings. Insert the bolt through the bearings with any necessary spacers.
Tighten two nuts on the bottom of the bolt. It should be snug, but still allow the bolt to rotate easily.
Put in lathe tool holder and begin hobbing. 200-400rpm seems to be working fine for M3, M4 hobbing.

Filament Spool holder for MPCNC with easy release clamp.
The Filament Spool should be above the Machine. It can be fixed to the edge of the table.
The threaded rod is 8mm in diameter and about 15cm long.
2 Bearings are something like 608-2RS 608 RS (8x22x7).
The pipe diameter is 15mm, but I included OpenSCAD file for customizing it.
Variables:
Pipe_D - is the diameter of pipe.
Holder_Height - height of the base part
PART - what part to print (0-4).

If you find that clamp is too tight, you can make it warn (in case of PLA) and stretch a bit.

09.03.17
Also made a simplified top part, without a clamp.

This sign can be found on the side of a road.

A type of road that can be found in-between states.

This president served after WWII and during a part of the Cold War which led to the creation of this idea.

This idea was created for military purposes, but is commonly thought of as civilian only today.

The Object: The object is an interstate highway sign.

Details about the Object: The object has the president’s name on it, and was held by the president, the sign itself is still up today, there are pictures of the president with this object.

President: Dwight Eisenhower(1953-1961) Republican Party

Presidential Role & Contribution
Commander in Chief
Executive order (Federal-Aid Highway Act of 1956)

Impact on America/ Significance
This artifact was used to mark the creation of the interstate highway system which is still used today.
I chose this President and artifact because I think Eisenhower and the interstate highway system is one of the most overlooked achievements and most overlooked presidents in our history and in classes we do not talk about either of these at all, but it is such an important development in today’s society.

Works Cited

U.S Government. (2015 , March 15). Dwight D. Eisenhower. Retrieved February 28, 2017

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System#/media/File:Eisenhower_Interstate_System_sign.jpg

Design by Kevin Betts

Clues

He tried to courage world peace and ended World War I
The book form represents a document that he made on January 10, 1920
This object is founded by the 28th president of the United States

Significant Research

The Object:
Book of “League of Nations”

Details:
A book representing the document of the League of Nations. After World War I president Woodrow Wilson wanted world peace so he created an intergovernmental organization on January 10, 1920 called the League of Nations to end wars and conflict between countries.

President:
Thomas Woodrow Wilson
Served- 1913 to 1921
Political party?

Contribution:
Chief Diplomat- Encourage world peace and resolve violence between countries.

Significance: President Wilson was elected as the 28th president, replacing William Howard Taft. President Wilson became president while world War I was still going on. He created a 14-point plan with the League of Nations as a major act to make world peace, but we still had World War II. He tried to encourage world peace and resolve conflict between nations. Wilson represented the democratic party, and took many actions during his presidency.

Impact on the United States:
I chose this artifact because it represents a very important act of my president. As one of Wilson's major acts the treaty of the League of Nations tried to encourage world peace and to end future wars and international disputes. This act made president Wilson known for what he did.

Citations

League of Nations. (n.d.). Retrieved April 19, 2017, from http://www.woodrowwilsonhouse.org/league-nations

Take on the role of an antiques appraiser and research this artifact. Which president is associated with this artifact and what presidential power does it represent? The more information you provide, the more valuable the artifact.

This 3D printable model was created by a student in Ms. Relator's US Government class at Dominion HS in Virginia. Find out more about the Mystery Artifact lesson at https://www.lcps.org/Page/186358

Mystery artifact created by,
Grecia Zelaya

-Took Place in Camp David Accords
-This president negotiated with Israel and Egypt
-He entered into Democratic Party in 1976
Can you guess which president?

The Object: Chess Board

Details about the Object:

President: Jimmy Carter, Served 1977-1981, Democratic

Presidential Role: Chief Diplomat

Contribution:
President Carter invited Sadat, President of Egypt, and Israeli President Menachem Begin, to Camp David in Maryland. It began September 5, 1978- lasted for 13 days. Purpose was to speak of issues between the countries. Mainly, they wanted to end state of war. While at the camp, all three presidents bonded by playing a game of chess (Britannica 2017).

Impact on America/ Significance
Why is this important to American history?
There had a been an ongoing struggle between all countries. President Carter took it in his hands to bring the presidents to a place where they'd be able to spend time together, to discuss all issues and bring it to an end. Since there wasn't any kind of communication, this camp was the way to start a relationship with Israel & Egypt.

"I chose this President and artifact because he is a president that wanted to create peace purely by just talking. He took the presidents to a camp, where they got to know each other and talk by themselves solely."

WORKS CITED

Jimmy Carter. (2017). In Encyclopædia Britannica. Retrieved from http://school.eb.com/levels/high/article/Jimmy-Carter/20545

Trailers set up at Camp David for members of the Israeli and Egyptian delegations Menachem Begin stayed in the Birch cabin. He played chess on the deck outside with Zbigniew Brzezinski Source:

Blog Archive. (2012, April 14). About Camp David. Retrieved April 19, 2017, from https://aboutcampdavid.blogspot.com/2012/04/camp-david-summit-1978.html

Mystery artifact created by,

Design by Ryan Williams

This object represents a president and his corrupt cabinet
This object represents a name of something major that happened during their presidency
Was involved in a big oil scandal
Propaganda representing the big controversy during Harding's presidency. Warren G Harding and his cabinet.

Presidential Role & Contribution
Chief Legislator- He negotiated with congress to pass or veto laws.
Chief Executive- He made all the important decisions for our country during his presidency, and held discussions with other foreign leaders.
Chief of Party- Being a republican he was the head of the Republican party.

Contribution: Tea Pot Dome Scandal
His cabinet took bribes from big oil companies and leased federal oil at rates without competitive bidding. This happened at oil reserves in Wyoming and California.

Significance of Object:

Republicans in Congress easily got the President's signature on their bills. They eliminated wartime controls and slashed taxes, established a Federal budget system, restored the high protective tariff, and imposed tight limitations upon immigration. This president’s cabinet had one of the first corrupt cabinets ever.
*It is said to be true that when this president died he also had a teapot next to his death bed, that holds a lot of irony.

Sources:
Warren harding - Google Search. (n.d.). Retrieved February 22, 2017, from https://www.google.com/search?q=warren%2Bharding&safe=strict&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiAvcOtvaTSAhXmhFQKHa3ADrkQ_AUICCgB&biw=1366&bih=638#safe=strict&tbm=isch&q=warren harding teapot dome scandal&imgrc=N9ZEBF5pfOhQUM:

Warren G. Harding. (2015, March 15). Retrieved February 22, 2017, from https://www.whitehouse.gov/1600/presidents/warrenharding

The Editors of Encyclopædia Britannica. (2015, October 27). Warren G. Harding. Retrieved February 22, 2017, from https://www.britannica.com/biography/Warren-G-Harding

Clues
  1. He is a founding father
  2. He wrote the first drafts of the U.S. Constitution, co-wrote the Federalist Papers and sponsored the Bill of Rights.
  3. He was the fourth president of the United States of America

Significance & Research

The object: Brown metal chair

Details about the object: It was used while writing important documents for the United States of America. I left out any information involving his name. He sat in this chair while writing documents for America.

President: James Madison March 4, 1809 – March 4, 1817

Presidential Role & Contribution
Chief Legislator
He wrote major document of america sitting on that chair, the first drafts of the U.S. Constitution, co-wrote the Federalist Papers and sponsored the Bill of Rights.

"I chose this president because he helped America developed a major document of America that is still used to this day"

Mystery artifact created by,

Marley Guilfoyle

This object represents a policy that this president advocated.
It is only a symbol, not a tangible object.
He served for 8 years.

The Object: Baseball Bat

Details about the Object: A baseball bat with the phrase, "Big Stick".

President: Theodore Roosevelt, 1901-1909, Republican and Progressive

Presidential Role: Chief Diplomat

Contribution: The Big Stick Policy was a part of Roosevelt’s international relations policy. It explained relations with domestic political leaders, and his approach to issues with monopolies and trade unions.

Impact on America/ Significance
:The quote that Roosevelt said was, “Speak softly, but carry a big stick. It promotes the idea of staying peaceful, while still keeping it known that military action is an option.

  • Stay calm and only fight back if it is necessary.

I wanted to research this president because he created a major symbol that is still known today. Even though it was a political cartoon, it still made a big impact. It promoted a message to other political leaders that America could stay calm, but also have a military present if needed. It made America a world power.

Works Cited:
The Editors of Encycyclopaedia Britannica. (2012, August 27). Big Stick Policy. Retrieved
February 3, 2017, from http://www.britannica.com/event/Big-stick-policy

(n.d.). Retrieved February 03, 2017, from http://kids.britannica.com/comptons/art-12346/A-cartoon- from-1905-shows-US-president-Theodore-Roosevelt-using (2017, February 28). Retrieved February 28, 2017, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Stick_ideology

At approximately 1:00 PM on Monday, February 27th, 2017, Elon Musk, SpaceX founder, CEO, and CTO announced that, near the end of 2018, two private citizens will be launched to the moon. Musk said the rocket used will be a Falcon Heavy mounted with the Dragon V2 capsule, which will be the homes of these two billionaire space tourists for about seven days. The exact price has not been stated, but my personal estimate is approximately $60 Million per person.

A full description of the events can be found at spacex.com/news/2017/02/27/spacex-send-privately-crewed-dragon-spacecraft-beyond-moon-next-year

Other SpaceX designs

I've produced several other SpaceX designs including SpaceX's Mars vehicle, if you are interested in them, check out my SpaceX collection.

If you are interested in making modifications to my design, check out my Onshape file at https://cad.onshape.com/documents/d0c6ad1d4fac799ab6829ae1/w/bc1f67580d7b869cfe7930c3/e/d44353a2111fe3dc6cfd1812

title: Fixed Single/Double cooling fan with Effector hook mounts

description.text:
I remixed this fan shroud because the original remixer didn't respond to a comment that he had a bug. If you print this for one fan, it retains little blocks that are required when you have two fans - to stop one fan from back-feeding into the other, but when it was remixed into a single fan shroud, the blocks were left in so that only half of the lower ring feeds.

I have also added two partially parametric hooks which are meant to let this device hang from an effector that does not have a wade mount.. Couple days later I realized that I had uploaded testing parameters, not anything that might actually work, so I re-uploaded it all.

So, I fixed two bugs in the code, wrote a tiny bit of my own code, and finallygot the version I wanted to have printed. My two 30mm fans were attached I installed it...and every time I tried to use the cooling fan the printer freaked, it noted that it was heating the hotend, but the hotend seemed to be cooling and that could be a runaway. It aborted and shut everything down. I had to power down to recover, M999 would not work.

What was happening was that the blower was just plain too high. It was blowing on the hot block, not on the print.

I thought about fixing this. It would require a lengthening of the central body of, well, maybe a cm. The fan should stay where it is (meaning that it should not be lowered maybe it should be raised and angled, and there should be a slot in the blower ring for the wires For a two fan setup it should replace one of the blocks that I ifed out (and it can't just be a cut, it has to be shaped and blocks in the blower ring have to be installed. Maybe a cylinder in a cyinder For a single fan system, it has to be a cut through the wade mount helper hole opposite the fan, and the blocks to the delivery tube can't block the wade mount and the wade mount should not block the wire exit. This implies that this drawing has to be done after the wade mount helper tunes are drawn, which would be very late in the draw.

OK, but I don't want to do that now - and I don't see this as useful as long as it is constrained to blow on the hot block. I am going to try something else.

title: Hoenir - Airsoft Ballistic Knife
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi All

This project is pretty cool, it's a ballistic knife, wich means the blade shoots out out the handle !
You will need a compression spring, 10mm in diameter 30mm when compressed and something like 70mm or a bit more when uncompressed.
I used the springs in an old Well bipod (there are 2 in each "leg").
Use a bit of epoxy or hot glue to attach the spring to the bottom of the handle.

You will also need a 25mm m3 screw.

You can print the blade (use flexible filament if you want to shoot at people), or print the blade mold (m3 screws to assemble the 2 parts of the mold) and cast flexible resin inside to get a safe flexible blade. I used this method to make about 20 blades with no problem.

Like my stuff ? Follow me !
Love it ? Tip me ;)

License is non commercial. Want to sell my stuff ? Send me a message ;)

comments.text: Great design! One suggestion I'd make is to modify it to accept standard airsoft AEG springs, which are powerful, cheap, and easy to access for airsoft players. I ended up modifying mine a bit to accept one instead of a 10mm diameter spring (I won't publish the results, in accordance to the no derivatives license) and it shoots impressively far - I can get a good 40-50 feet of range out of it from a flat initial trajectory.
comments.author: karlzhao314

comments.text:

comments.text: Pretty simple - I just bored out the hole in the middle to 10mm. The way I did it specifically (given my complete inexperience with working with meshes) was just loading it into 3DSMax, creating a 10mm diameter cylinder and positioning it inside the handle, and doing a boolean subtraction operation on it, but I'm sure there were far simpler or more efficient ways to do it.

A second look at the Oroville dam using ASTER data ("ASTER GEDEM is a product of METI and NASA").

Two relief maps have been calculated using 10,000 data points centered near the dam. The vertical scale has been exaggerated to more clearly show detail. As before a map, ver_1, has been calculated using an openSCAD surface file. A second map, ver_2, was formed by stacking 10,000 rectangular bricks with heights proportional to the data points. Flat surfaces representing the height of each pixel can be seen in the stl file. It has visual appeal and is a reminder of the limitations of the data. Fortran and openSCAD code are included.

A new view of the dam was added on March 3, 2017

Looking at the raw data, the height of the lake is given as 248 meters, the height of the river below the dam 70 meters, and the height of the dam ca. 275 to 280 meters. A scale factor of 0.04 plus a base of 2 was used to create the maps - see the fortran code.

One can check the maps against Google earth images. Going back to 2013 in Google earth history the water level behind the dam seems to be similar to that in the ASTER data. The entrance to the spillway can be seen at the left of the dam. There is a hint of a pathway at the left that could either be the spillway or the emergency spillway.

comments.text: I've added a view of the Oroville dam that shows the spillway more clearly - od_ver_1b.stl and od_ver_2b.stl.  The area, down to the Feather river, that includes both the main spillway and the emergency spillway is now included.  The data was taken when the river flow was low; sediment bars in the Feather are visible.

title: Filament Tube Base for MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X

description.text:
One drawback of the filament feeding tubes on the MakerBot Replicator printers is the bracket integral to the frame of the printer, meant to hold the tube at its base, while the other end, plugged into the extruder, moves about above.  This 2mm thick piece of metal slowly tears away at the tubing, until the tubing tends to come loose at the top of the bracket.  This Base allows the tubes to be held firmly, while easily, and firmly attaching to the existing bracket.  This can be used with the OEM filament holders, or with customer-provided other means of delivering the filament.  
I believe this Thing will work with both the MakerBot Replicator 2 and 2X, but I do not have a Rep 2 to know this for sure.

The Tube Base is best printed with ABS.  The STL file compensates for ABS shrinkage.  I would print this standing on the bottom edge, with or without a Raft.  Standard Resolution.  Use support (HIPS support makes life much easier if you have a Rep 2X).  Shells = 3, Infill = 15%, ABS extruder temp = 240C.  If using HIPS support, temp = 230C (don't choose MakerBot Dissolvable Filament material choice in MakerWare, as this will set the temp to 250C, which will fuse the HIPS together too much, and make it hard to remove).  HBP temp = 115C.  
After printing, enlarge the tube holes with a 1/4" drill bit.  A good sharp bit should easily follow the printed hole (best to hold the plastic by hand, to allow the drill to do its thing, but go slow and be careful), and the resulting hole should fit most 1/4" tubing snugly.  
You will need to unload your filament, and remove the filament tubes from the printer.  Press the tubing into what you want to be the top of the holder, and then if, because the tubing is bent, it catches, rotate the tubing while pushing, or tweak it a bit as you push it further.  Make the tubing flush with the bottom of the holder.  Align both tubes pointing toward the back of the holder, and press it into place, using the slots in the back, onto the existing bracket.  The tubes should slip into place as they would if placed individually, and this and the flexibility of the ABS should make for a snug fit.  The holder has clearance to accommodate the electronics mesh-covered cable running up the back of the printer.  Attach the tubes (or tube) to the extruder(s), and you are ready to load filament and print.

comments.text: I'll be adding another Thing, an adapter to fit the other end of the filament feeder tube, which will allow the tube to easily be attached to custom extruders which don't have a raised boss and which are such a tight fit that it is difficult to reattach the tube on the fly, such as when changing filaments in mid-build.  This will be called Tubing Adapter.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
X-Carve dust collector
There are quite a few dust collectors for the X-Carve both on Thingiverse and other places. I’ve found most of these too complicated or too bulky. I wanted something that is small yet effective. This is the design I decided was the best for me.
The collector is mounted on the X-carriage, thus not following the movements in Z direction up and down. This means that brushes are not necessary, but it needs a somewhat flat surface on the stock that is being carved. In other words, sheet material is best, that’s what I mostly use.
You will need the following 3d printed parts:
1 Dust collector bottom
1 Dust collector lid
2 Pipe holder X-carriage
2 Tightening knob
You will also need the following:
2 M4 30mm screws, the heads must be grinded so that they fit inside the tightening knobs
2 M4 washers
2 M4 nuts
4 M4 10mm screws
3 tiny screws to fix the pipe to the Dust collector lid
1 35 mm pipe, wall thickness 1mm, length 200mm
You will also need a M4 tap to create the threads in the X-carriage for the pipe holder.

Assembly and mounting:
Glue the 2 pieces, lid and bottom, together.
Mount the pipe holders with double sided tape to the X-carriage. They must be mounted flush with the left edge of the carriage, and flush with the upper and lower edges of the carriage. Drill the holes and make the threads. Mount the holders in place with the 4 10 mm screws
Now it is time to mount the pipe to the collector. Drill 3 equally distant holes close to one end of the pipe, big enough for the tiny screws you’ve selected. Make holes in the sleeve of the collector for the screws, do not mount the pipe yet.
Place the pipe in the holders and mount the collector with the tiny screws
Insert the nut in the pipe holders. insert the 30 mm screws in the tightening knobs. And put the washers in place. Now screw the tightening knobs into the pipe holders.
If you are using homing switches you might have to move the X-carriage stop a little bit to the right.
When using the dust collector, you must have it at least 3-5 mm above the surface, if lower you reduce the airflow and the efficiency of the collector.
You are done, HAPPY DUST FREE CARVING!

If you find my design useful please give me a TIP

How to use it:

  • Swing the collector to the left side.
  • Mount the router bit.
  • Set Z-zero position and XY position
  • Jog the Z axis up so the collector can swing under the router bit
  • Center the collector under the router bit and adjust the level over your material 3-5 mm.
  • Tighten the knobs so the collector is fixed.
  • Start the carving.

Take on the role of an antiques appraiser and research this artifact. Which president is associated with this artifact and what presidential power does it represent? The more information you provide, the more valuable the artifact.

This 3D printable model was created by a student in Ms. Relator's US Government class at Dominion HS in Virginia. Find out more about the Mystery Artifact lesson at https://www.lcps.org/Page/186358

Mystery artifact created by,
Dilara Beg

1. President made a peace treaty with Israel and Egypt
  2. Played Chess with Prime minister and president
  3. Created at a presidential weekend retreat

The Object: Chess piece from Camp David

Details about the Object: The chess piece was a part of the set at Camp David that the President used during his stay. On the bottom of the chess piece I added “Camp David” to help identify the object.

President: Jimmy Carter, 1977-1981, Democratic Party

Presidential Role: Chief Diplomat
Presidential Contribution:
Peace treaty Camp David Accords of 1978 with counties Egypt and Israel.
Before the Camp David Accords was established president Sādāt of introduced the idea of a strong relationship with the U.S. The first lady, Rosalynn Carter suggested that her husband, Jimmy Carter, invite the prime minister and president to Camp David where the relative privacy and seclusion might provide a setting for a breakthrough.

I chose this President and artifact because it signifies the framework for a historic peace treaty that was concluded between the three countries. Three months after the treaty was signed there was a diplomatic relationship between the countries. As a result, Israel withdrew from West Bank and Gaza which helped introduce the Palestinian self-government.

1. Gave a speech about religious freedom and how his religion would not affect his decisions as president.
  2. I was told that after the president was assassinated , the rosary was found in this presidents pocket.
  3. First Roman Catholic president ever.

The Object: rosary

Details about the Object: you cannot see it on the 3D object, but on the actual rosary it says his name. "A woman who went to the same church as this president, St. Aidan’s Catholic Church in Massachusetts found it and gave it to me."

President: John F. Kennedy, president #35, Democratic party

Presidential Role
Chief Executive

Presidential Contribution
This president gave a speech saying that the decisions he makes will not be effected by his religion, “I believe in an America where the separation of church and state is absolute, where no Catholic prelate would tell the president (should he be Catholic) how to act, and no Protestant minister would tell his parishioners for whom to vote” (NPR). This is a direct quote from his speech. The speech was given on September 12, 1960 in front of thousands of people and it was directed to reverend Meza, and Reverend Reck.
"I picked this president because I wanted to learn more about what he did to help our country. I also wanted to know why this president changed so many people’s lives."

I chose this President and artifact because he was the first president that was roman catholic, and I chose the rosary because the rosary represents a lot in the catholic religion. This speech was important because he told the American people that he thought that separation of church and state are very important to him.

title: Cigarette and Flip Lighter Fast Case

description.text:
The case works without any moving parts, so it is easy to make and use. It carries up to 5 regular size cigarretes and a regular Flip Lighter; the main characteristicas are:

Small.
Slim.
Soft to the touch, no hard edges.
Easy to use.

The cigarettes are hold in the case by pressure on the top of the filter, so no damage is done to the cigarette body. To remove thecigarrete just push through the window of any cigarrete compartment and move the filter upward until the tip sticks out from the case, then just pick it up with your fingers.

The Flip Lighter stand place allows to easily remove de lighter by pushing it from the bottom up; but even though, the lighter should stay in place if the case is flipped upside down. The lighter can be lit when is in place, so no need to remove to used, this even helps on windy conditions.

Models for cigarretes and lighter used:

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2071524

comments.text: Wonderful cigarette holder. Any way you can modify to hold 10? Essentially mirror the object without the lighter slot on the back, that way you can push 5 cigarettes up from the front, and 5 from the back. This would be a great daily driver, but if I've got errands to run after work, 5 wont cut it haha!

title: Tubing Adapter for 1/4" filament feeder tubes.

description.text: This adapter is to make changing filament during printing easier.  It attaches to the end of the tube which feeds filament to the extruder.  Some custom extruders are a tight fit, even though they have a hole to accommodate the tube.  This can be a problem when trying to quickly change filament during a print, and you can't afford to knock the extruder out of position.  This adapter should fit most flexible tubing snugly, and slip right into the hole on the top of an extruder which doesn't have such a boss built in.

This Thing should be printed in ABS for flexibility.  It needs to be Scaled in MakerWare to 101.1%.  Print with the largest diameter end down.  A Raft is not necessary.  ABS extruder 240C.  HPB = 115C  Standard resolution.

author: KHecker

title: drawing table Marker/Material box
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you have a drawing table? does that table tilt? Do your markers/pens/everything else Roll off the table? Does that DRIVE YOU STINKING CRAZY????.

Well, hopefully, you're not as neurotic. BUT you'll still love this little aid I've designed. Granted, I made it for my art markers, (Three brands on display here: Shinhan Touch, Copic, and Spectra). Liner sleeves and others also fit. Not only that, It has space at the front for random tidbits such as erasers and leads. Super cheap as well! Check instructions and Send pictures!

If you tip, Double awesome! But if not: At least send a picture, that's a kindness in itself.

Printing? you LASER CUT THIS.

So, Instructions: Use 3 mm material of your choice. Preferably, something that you can paste later, as kerf hasn't been accounted for. I used 3 mm MDF. you may use 3 mm plywood for a prettier finish as well.

Word of advice, it was created for a 18 mm thick table. Is your table any different? Measure it first! It's an easy thing to change with any vector editing program.

Be well!

author: heribertovalle

title: Masson jar lamp by Samuel Bernier, Project RE_

description.text:
An other cool way to reuse a Masson jar using an IKEA suspension kit and funky 3D printing.
More about Project RE_ on http://www.instructables.com/id/Project-RE-by-Samuel-Bernier/

All you will need is a 3 inches wide glass jar (lid size), the 6$ IKEA suspension kit, a light bulb and this file.
Print the shade, the bigger opening facing the table. Set the support angle to 30 degrees. The part takes about 3 hours to print in normal mode. 0.25 thickness. Then pass the cable trough the hole, screw the light bulb and then screw the cleaned jar. You got the lamp! -Sam

title: Desktop AA and AAA battery Stand

description.text:
Because I do so much drone stuff, and I have wireless keyboards and mice, I go through a to of battery charges. So I keep my rechargeable batteries on my desk. I was using a different stand, but it held the batteries too loose, and i always stuck the AAA between them and they just fell over a lot.  
So, i did this one to keep it all clean and maximize use of the space.
Just designed in CAD. Cut out holes for batteries and tried to use as little plastic as possible to get the job done.

comments.text:
been using it for a few days now....
It is an interesting design that works well if you mostly use AA batteries. Unfortunately it will hide the smaller AAAs behind the larger AA batteries.
I may create an alternative over the weekend.
